Award.AwardTitle: COLLAB. RESEARCH: ARTS: Revising the classification of the temperate zone's largest angiosperm genus (Carex, Cyperaceae), and training the next generation of sedge systematists
Award.AbstractNarration:
A team of three lead scientists from The Morton Arboretum, Washington State University, and McGill University and 14 collaborating scientists from ten countries are undertaking a taxonomic revision of the flowering plant genus Carex, an ecologically and geographically widespread plant group with more than 2,000 species. The project will (1) develop new tools for online biodiversity data management; (2) solidify a broad international team through online collaboration, international field-collecting expeditions, and training of students and young researchers; (3) estimate the phylogenetic placement of ~1,360 species based on DNA sequences; (4) assemble a database of morphological, climatic, and biogeographic data; and (5) publish a revision of the higher level taxonomy of Carex.

The taxonomy of global plant and animal groups provides information essential to species and habitat conservation, ecological restoration, and our understanding of biodiversity. This project will produce a phylogenetic framework for one of the largest flowering plant genera, providing an essential tool for understanding global plant biodiversity. At the same time, this project (1) trains the next generation of sedge taxonomists; (2) increases taxonomic readiness in students and teachers; (3) publishes diverse datasets online through eMonocot and Encyclopedia of Life; and (4) contributes to global biodiversity conservation through an enhanced barcoding resource and new informatic tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Systematic revisions of organismal groups (lineages) with global distributions are plagued by the difficulties of inspecting material from wide-ranging field sites and museum collections, coordinating efforts across continents and time zones, and rectifying regional and global ideas about diversity. Yet revisions of global lineages provide essential information for understanding diversification patterns and providing a roadmap for biodiversity preservation. In this project, we launched an integrated set of global research and education activities in the sedge genus Carex (Cyperaceae) that broaden taxonomic expertise across a wide range of skill levels and strengthen the global taxonomic community. Carex is among the four largest flowering plant genera worldwide and has not been revised globally since 1909. The classification within Carex (“sections”) is the usual gateway into species identification in Carex, and researchers typically circumscribe Carex research projects according to sections. A revised sectional classification would greatly facilitate both conservation of and research on the genus.

Our specific themes and associated goals were:

Research Community and Tools: Create a virtual research environment for the Cyperaceae community — We collaborated with developers at ViBRANT/Scratchpads to develop new tools for data management and collaboration in a virtual research environment we have established for this project. These tools have enabled efficient collaboration in specimen databasing, data sharing, and taxonomic revision, allowing us to tackle a huge genus and providing new tools for revisionary systematics.

Molecular Phylogeny: Create a phylogenetic framework for Carex — We have currently sampled ca.1,240 of an estimated 2,000 species for at least 3 genes per species, and identified major lineages that we can use as a framework in revising the sectional classification. This work has involved collaboration of greater than 40 Carex researchers and students world-wide. We are still in the process of adding several hundred additional samples and we expect tohe final sampling from work supported by this grant to be greater than 1,600 Carex species.

Traits and Diversification: Assemble a database of traits to test diversification patterns and form the basis for predictive classification and monography — We are in various stages of assembling databases of morphological, climatic, and biogeographic data to investigate the pattern and tempo of ecological, morphological, and lineage diversification in sedges. Some of these studies have been published (see NSF reports), and others are in the process of being prepared for publication.

Taxonomic Synthesis: Revise the sectional classification of Carex — A robust phylogeny of the genus is only half of the sectional revision; the other half is identifying characteristics that define lineages, and assigning valid names to those lineages. We have used joint meetings and workshops to synthesize the data for a revised sectional classification which should be ready for submission in 2017.

This study has resulted in eight major publications directly associated with the funding for WSU, with numerous other publications from collaborators at the Morton Arboretum and elsewhere also facilitated by this research funding. Multiple additional publications that were supported by this funding are in various stages of preparation. We have created a detailed understanding of Carex diversification and are making major reorganizations of the Carex classification that will be of use to researchers and lay-people interested in identification and conservation of sedge diversity.
